etymology.description: Depicts two parallel strokes -> represents the number two
etymology.interpretation: The character 二(二) (èr, "two") consists of two horizontal lines that visually represent the concept of 'two'. This method of using parallel strokes to denote numbers is a straightforward representation of quantity, similar to how 一(一) (yī, "one") represents 'one' and 三(三) (sān, "three") represents 'three'.

examples.chinese: 我有二支笔(我有二支筆)。
他买了二个苹果(他買了二個蘋果)，我们一起分享(我們一起分享)。
examples.pinyin: Tā mǎi le èr gè píngguǒ, wǒmen yīqǐ fēnxiǎng.
examples.english: He bought two apples, and we shared them together.
